#Text=Eastern Cape
#Text=Eastern
#Text=Cape
#Text=is in South Africa and stretches along the Indian Ocean between Western Cape and KwaZulu-Natal .
#Text=Understand
#Text=The Eastern Cape province includes the former " homelands " of Transkei and Ciskei .
#Text=With a long coastline on the Indian Ocean it offers great beaches as well as several very interesting National Parks .
#Text=Its population is mainly Xhosa-speaking and the province is home to several of South Africa`s most important persons in the fight against Apartheid ( e. g.
#Text=Nelson Mandela , Thabo Mbeki , Steve Biko and Oliver Tambo ) .
#Text=It 's still a poor province especially in the former homelands but beautiful and not so touristy .
#Text=Regions
#Text=The Eastern Cape can be divided in the following regions :
#Text=Cities
#Text=-
#Text=The capital of the Eastern Cape
#Text=- the largest city in the province is connected to the rest of the country by flights , motorways and rail .
#Text=- the second largest city is accessible by plane , car and train and is the starting point for traveling to the former Transkei and Wild Coast .
#Text=- heart of the Settler Country offering traditional atmosphere .
#Text=( formerly called Umtata ) - the main city in the former Transkei .
#Text=- the capital of the Karoo desert and a national heritage site .
#Text=Other destinations
#Text=- backpackers haven with two famous hostels and a great atmosphere .
#Text=- high up in the Amathole mountain range , surrounded by indigenous forests with hiking trails and waterfalls .
#Text=National parks
#Text=At least 400 elephants all sizes , great accommodation , book through parks Board , 30 mins by car from Port Elizabeth
#Text=( Book through the Parks Board ) phone : +27 21 423 8005 .
#Text=Wonderful coastal scenery with great hikes and walks , nice accommodation , between Plettenberg Bay and Humansdorp including the famous Otter Trail .
#Text=Other nature reserves
#Text=,
#Text=Commando Drift Nature Reserve , 60 km east from Cradock .
#Text=Dwesa and Cwebe Nature Reserve , dutywa .
#Text=Two small reserves separated by the Mbashe River , next to the Indian Ocean near Elliotdale .
#Text=Private game reserves
#Text=Kragga Kamma Game Park .
#Text=Seaview Game & Lion Park , ☏ +2742 378-1702 .
#Text=Schotia Safaris Game Reserve , ☏ +2742 235-1436 .
#Text=Huge stock of game with free roaming lions .
#Text=One gets the safari feeling here without paying through the nose .
#Text=Ggame drive , meal and drink R600pp or staying overnight , with evening and morning drive , meals and drinks for R1200pp. .
#Text=Shamwari Game Reserve , ☏ +2742 203-1111 .
#Text=The most well-known and luxurious of the private game reserves in the Eastern Cape .
#Text=By car
#Text=The main motorway in the province is the N2 .
#Text=It runs along the coast from Cape Town via the Garden Route , Port Elizabeth , the Transkei and further through KwaZulu-Natal and Mpumalanga .

#Text=The road condition is mainly excellent except in the Transkei ( Do not travel the Transkei portion of the N2 at night as the potholes can be deep and there are often stray animals ie cows and goats wandering around ) .
#Text=From Cape Town
#Text=Follow the N2 via the Overberg and into the Garden Route
#Text=From Gauteng , Free State , Limpopo and Mpumalanga
#Text=Follow the N1 toll road south until Colesberg , then follow the N9 from there towards Graaff-Reinet and George or follow first the N9 and then the N10 towards Port Elizabeth .
#Text=Avoid driving the N9 and N10 at night as game often wander onto the road at night and accidents are not uncommon .
#Text=A full grown kudu or other large antelope can cause some severe damage to you and your vehicle .
#Text=By plane
#Text=Port Elizabeth and East London are the main national airports both with several flights daily to other South African destinations , but no international flights .
#Text=By train
#Text=Spoornet operates regular trains from Johannesburg to both Port Elizabeth and East London .

#Text=There is also a once-weekly service from Cape Town to East London , a daily service between Grahamstown and Alicedale and a weekend-only service between East London and Mthatha ( via Amabele ) .
#Text=By car
#Text=Definitely the best option if you are more than two as several regions and some of the National Parks are n't accessible by public transport .
#Text=Road Conditions are mainly good but get informed before you start .
#Text=Car rental is available in larger cities and along the popular resorts of the Garden Route .
#Text=Be careful of wild animals , especially monkeys , on the road .
#Text=Be especially careful if driving at night .
#Text=By bus
#Text=The main companies cross the Eastern Cape on their way from Cape Town to Durban .
#Text=There are other main routes from Port Elizabeth and East London to Johannesburg .
#Text=The Baz Bus traverses the province on its Cape Town - Port Elizabeth - Durban run ; Port Elizabeth is a compulsory overnight stop .
#Text=Minibus services are available for local transport between neighbouring towns ( and also on several longer distances ) .
#Text=By train
#Text=With the limited range of railways this is n't really a viable option for touring the province .
#Text=However , the route from Grahamstown to Alicedale is very scenic and well worth doing .
#Text=The newly opened line from East London to Mthatha also traverses some dramatic scenery through the Wild Coast .
#Text=See
#Text=Port Elizabeth : the provincial capital and major transportation hub
#Text=East London : Gateway to the Wild Coast
#Text=Grahamstown : University town with a colonial English atmosphere
#Text=Graaff-Reinet : a national heritage site and the classical example of an inland town .
#Text=Wild Coast : spectacular scenery and only a few tourists make this an out-off-the-beaten track destination
#Text=Morgan 's Bay : Seaside village with magnificent cliffs that plunge into the sea .
#Text=Kei mouth : Southern gateway to the Wild Coast via one of South Africa 's two remain pontoon car ferries .
#Text=Tsitsikamma National Park : not as spectacular as some of the other National Parks it offers superb coastlines , whale watching and excellent hiking .
#Text=Addo Elephant National Park : famous for the elephants this park is after the unification with Zuurberg NP one of South Africa`s largest .
#Text=Also has lion .
#Text=Mountain Zebra National Park - small , but only very few people there .
#Text=See the endangered Mountain Zebras .
